content.full_text:
Asa Lee Davison to Abraham Lincoln, 23 November 18481 I have to thank you^for^a report from thePatent officeand several of your eloquent speeches– Hope for a continuance of like favours– Inclosed you will see one of the manybeautiesof theSub-treasury, by which you will see there is due me at the Patent office $20.2which they have no way of sending to me– And I must call there for it or send an

agent– And altho' it is with extreme reluctance that I would burthen you with such a matter, I can

think of no other way to obtain the money, than by asking you to get it for me in

gold and sending me a current bank bill, by mail– for which I have written an order

below–
paragraphs: Asa Lee Davison to Abraham Lincoln, 23 November 18481 I have to thank you^for^a report from thePatent officeand several of your eloquent speeches– Hope for a continuance of like favours– Inclosed you will see one of the manybeautiesof theSub-treasury, by which you will see there is due me at the Patent office $20.2which they have no way of sending to me– And I must call there for it or send an
agent– And altho' it is with extreme reluctance that I would burthen you with such a matter, I can
think of no other way to obtain the money, than by asking you to get it for me in
gold and sending me a current bank bill, by mail– for which I have written an order

footnotes.text: 1Asa Lee Davison wrote this letter in its entirety.
2The enclosed “beauty” was not with the letter and has not been located.

Inclosed you will see one of the manybeautiesof theSub-treasury, by which you will see there is due me at the Patent office $20.2which they have no way of sending to me–  And I must call there for it or send an
               agent–  And altho'[although] it is with extreme reluctance that I would burthen you with such a matter, I can
               think of no other way to obtain the money, than by asking you to get it for me in
               gold and sending me a current bank bill, by mail– for which I have written an order
